seg.seg: [Prince Uttara]: “My dear mother! Do tell [my] dear father ..."
[The king]: "Do not be afraid!” The Brahmins ...
... after grasping (with one hand) the prince (Uttara) [and] with the second hand the golden ...
... [my] dear (god)-like son, hard (for me to give away) ...
How can I give [away] Uttara, my dear son of divine appearance who is difficult to let go? I do not pay attention to my own sorrow … (cf 240)
... with the (knife) of ...(I want to smash? the falsehood) into little pieces ...
... [The king] sits. Thereupon (dragging the prince) Uttara the Brahmins ...

p.note: The paper is severely damaged and the script is partly erased, esp. on the verso. To be judged from the script and the general disposition, this leaf belongs to a different manuscript than the other Araṇemijātaka pieces , , and .
Probably the small fragment b 4 is a parallel, both have ammakki.

The Berlin parallel a 5 seems to have the more consistent text in accordance with the Vedic ritual of giving water to honor a guest (cf. 34 s.v. argha-). Despite the discussion by 240, fn. 13, the notion of "golden water" is not attested in Sanskrit. Therefore, the adjective golden rather is the epithet of the container of the gift water. This, of course, presupposes that here both versions differ. A theoretical possibilty to assume a common text would be to restore to ysā(r)ṣṣe "bloody" (water) – note that THT 85 a 5 can in theory also be read (ys)[ā]rṣṣe –, but this does not make sense here.
The restoration (ñä)kte-yokäṃ is not completely certain but it makes good sense as transposition of Skt. deva-rūpa- "god-like".

In contrast to Couvreur, who did not propose any reading for the very damaged first line, based on an autopsy and with the help of the parallel Berlin text , one can read (and restore) still many signs.

Couvreur's restoration [ce]nä(n)ä(\) is not warranted, because fremdzeichen 〈na〉 is hardly ever used. Note that in the lacuna of the parallel text b 4 there is not enough space for this form cenän, but only for ceṃ from the near-deictic demonstrative se. The use of the recognitional pronoun seṃ makes more sense in this context.
